body.name: Weigh Anchor: A Jesse McDermitt Novel (Caribbean Adventure Series Book 26)
body.description: A lifelong friend finds something deep in the Everglades that is so very odd, that when he calls Jesse McDermitt, at first the semi-retired former special operator is in total disbelief. But he is also very intrigued, and the duo set out on another adventure reminiscent of their childhood days.But their youthful quest had been all about fun and make-believe. This one was real, waiting nearly a century to be discovered.There is another party interested in what Billy Rainwater stumbled upon. They have been searching for decades and will stop at nothing to recover what they believe to be not only their personal property, but their legacy. The Glades never gives up secrets readily.Deep in the River of Grass, untold dangers lurk, waiting to snatch the unwary. It raises its ugly head in the backcountry of the Middle Keys, as well. But when it finds its way into the parking lot of Jesse’s favorite watering hole, a line in the sand has to be drawn once again. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Wayne Stinnett is a great storyteller. I have read all his Jesse McDermitt novels and waiting for the next one. His Charity Styles novels are great also. Keep them coming.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Not Great
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed the book very much, but wanted more. The ending seemed a little rushed and incomplete. I still love Jesse and the other continuing characters and their desire and ability to do the right thing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome as always
reviews.reviewText: I'd so love to be friends with this group, what a life that would be. Would never have to worry about hardly anything as someone in this group could handle it! And that's not the best reason. Honest to goodness real, true, patriotic and loyal people. My kind of people. Never read a Jesse McDermitt book? Get reading; you'll not find a better series or author. Thanks, Wayne!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Solo Wayne is the way to go!
reviews.reviewText: After reading the co-authored 3 books, I was happy to dive into this. Not disappointed. The McDermitt saga continues and always has an ending to make you hunger for the next.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A real anchor.
reviews.reviewText: We need hero's that are strong, moral, ethical, and don't wear a cape. Thanks for a hero that thinks ahead of the situation and isn't flustered by the circumstances changing. Oh yeah, Jesse is consistent!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not his best.
reviews.reviewText: It almost feels like WS phoned this one in. There were potentially two good stories in this book. But the author just sort of glossed both of them over like maybe he was on a deadline to get the book published and didn't have enough time to tell the stories.It is sad really, the last few books have lacked the spark of the earlier ones of the series. I hope that Jesse hasn't run his course.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I love all the Jesse McDermitt novels but this my least favorite. I just couldn’t get really interested in it. It did get better towards the middle of the book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another fine read
reviews.reviewText: This was another fine read of Jessie and his Knuckle Dragging friends ! They never disappoint in their adventures and the trouble that follows them !Just sad I have to wait several more months till the next book in the series !!!!

I have always enjoyed the Jesse McDermitt books, but this one was disjointed, seemed to have storylines that should have been in separate books and felt like a rushed outcome. I enjoyed the book, but wished it could have been more like past books with fully fleshed out storylines.

reviews.reviewTitle: very poor (self absorbed Jesse/Wayne S character). writing is thin and one dimensional.
reviews.reviewText: Jesse (Wayne S.) wants to be the ultimate male. He really doesn’t treat others as equals. So he fills paragraphs with ultimate details of mechanical/marine/trucks. Boring. Fallen series, early ones weren’t bad but he never progressed, only filled pages. He thinks he treats his family well but in my opinion he “allows” women and kids to do things. I lived in Keys and Fla. for years and he is the last of a breed that I would of avoided like the plague.
